title: Tidy Tuesday 09-21-2021
description: Here is my attempt for tidy tuesday 09-21-21. The dataset is about the Emmy Awards.
contents:
library(tidytuesdayR)
library(tidyverse)         # for graphing and data cleaning





# Get the Data

# Read in with tidytuesdayR package 
# Install from CRAN via: install.packages("tidytuesdayR")
# This loads the readme and all the datasets for the week of interest

# Either ISO-8601 date or year/week works!

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2021-09-21')



    Downloading file 1 of 1: `nominees.csv`

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2021, week = 39)



    Downloading file 1 of 1: `nominees.csv`

nominees <- tuesdata$nominees

# Or read in the data manually

nominees <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-09-21/nominees.csv')





### Create a graph based on every category
nominees_types <- nominees %>%
  filter(year > 2010) %>%
  group_by(year, type) %>%
  summarize(count=n()) 


nominees_types %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = as.factor(year), y = count, fill = type)) + geom_col(position = "dodge") + 
  geom_text(aes(x = as.factor(year), y = count, label = count),
            position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), 
            vjust = -1, size = 2,
            fontface="bold", 
            family="Times") + 
  labs(title = "Emmy Awards Nominee and Winner from 2011 to 2021") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(axis.title.x = element_blank(), 
        axis.title.y = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(family = "Times"))




In here, we can clearly see that from 2011 to 2013, the number of nominee increased rapidly. However, the number of nominee in 2014 significantly dropped.
After a strange 2014, the number of nominee increased significantly every year from 1630 nominees in 2015 to 2152 nominees in 2019. Meanwhile, the number of winner remains relatively stable.

title: First Tidy Tuesday 09/08/2021
description: Here is my first tidy tuesday. It will improve over time!
contents:
library(tidyverse)         # for graphing and data cleaning





# Get the Data
constructors <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-09-07/constructors.csv')
constructor_standings <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-09-07/constructor_standings.csv')





constructor_standings %>%
  group_by(constructorId) %>%
  summarize(total_points = sum(points)) %>%
  filter(constructorId < 50) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = constructorId, y = total_points)) + geom_col(fill = "blue") + 
  labs(title = "The total number of points for the first 50 constructors")




For this weekâ€™s data, I decide to look into the constructor ID and the total number of points for the first 50 constructors. We can see that constructor number 6 - ferrari has the highest points of them all.
Right now, the question I have is that when I try to filter the top constructor and I try to make a geom_col, the graph is not looking great. The reason for that is because we have a lot of constructors and when I filter it, the constructor is really far apart. So how can I do it?
Moreover, I would love to know the name of the constructors. Is there any way to combine constructor_standings with constructors? I have tried full join but it does not look great.
